blog0.title: Week 1
blog0.blog: This week we learned how to loop through arrays and how to have the array print to DOM. We did projects that had us take 2 arrays and merge them into one, all in all they were pretty easy, I did not cry in the shower this week.

blog1.title: Week 2
blog1.blog: This week we worked on a project that generated a coin counter, and a project that converts temperature from Fahrenheit to Celsius and back again.

blog2.title: Week 3
blog2.blog: This week we learned about event listeners. We had 3 assignments that we used event listeners on, Dynamic Cards, Guinea Pig, and WYSIWYG.  WYSIWYG was by far the most challenging, there was a lot of layers to it.  All in all I feel like I have a pretty good grasp on event listeners at this point.

blog3.title: Week 4
blog3.blog: This week we worked on XHR requests. The great thing about XHR requests is it makes JS code look a little cleaner.  I love pulling an array from a JSON file rather than have a large array in my main file. Our first assignement we pulled from 2 different JSON files that work together to populate the results we wanted.

blog4.title: Week 5
blog4.blog: This week we learned about bootstrap. Bootstrap is a platform that allows universal styling.  It's a little generic looking but it is a good introduction to that type of styling.

blog5.title: Week 6
blog5.blog: We learned about Browserfy this week.  Working on 4-5 different javascript files is going to take getting used to, I do like that everything is separated, but It's difficult not being able to see all the code right infront of me at all times.

blog6.title: Week 7
blog6.blog: We did a group project this week called Chatty, it's a site that is like a group message board.  It has different users, and different preferences that each user can set. It was a good project overall, a little trying at times.  We also learned about promises, so far they are not to bad, but time will tell.

blog7.title: Week 8
blog7.blog: We learned about APIs this week. The most difficult thing I find about APIs is what to do with the data once you get it back, it's going to take getting used to pulling data back from something besides a local JSON file.

blog8.title: Week 9
blog8.blog: Today we learned about firebase, firebase is a place you can deploy sites you've created as well as put data to pull back to a site.  I also like that you can create a login feature for the site so you can keep track of who is loging in.

blog9.title: Week 10
blog9.blog: We did a group project this week called theme parks, we pulled data from firebase to create a theme park website.  It was a challenging project in that they kept changing the rules, JSON, and how it was supposed to layout.

blog_10.title: Week 11
blog_10.blog: We learned Angular this week, like Browserfy, it is several files rather than one, the difference is there is also an equal amounto f HTML files as well as service files which are used to pulling in data to use on the controller files.  It is a lot to look at and I find it easy to loose track of where I am on the projects but it seems very real world and useful.

blog_11.title: Week 12
blog_11.blog: We did our Capstone this week, it's our final project. My Capstone is a photo site called Photo Destination, it allows a user to upload images, favorite other users images and delete and edit your personal images.  Right now I am working on image upload which will allow a user to upload an image without copying a URL.

Project1.Title: Iife-Sandwich
Project1.Description: Create a sandwich generator using iifes.

Project2.Title: Seasonal Sales
Project2.Description: An online retail store that displays prices, and different products based on the season.

Project3.Title: Chatty Knockout Generals
Project3.Description: A group project where we created a chat forum.

Project5.Title: Angular Contacts
Project5.Description: A app that lets a user keep track of all their contacts, add new ones, and remove old ones.
